content:
I have a crush for Guitart. :heart:

More generally, I believe (and I'm not alone with this belief) that the French school of 2-category theory is a forgotten gem.

Remarques sur les machines et les structures, Cahiers de Topologie et Géométrie Différentielle Catégoriques, Tome 15 (1974) no. 2, pp. 113-144.
Décompositions et Lax-complétions, Cahiers de topologie et géométrie différentielle catégoriques, tome 15, no 2 (1974), p. 113-144.
Rélations et carrés exacts, Ann. SC. math. Québec, 1980, Vol. IV, No 2, pp. 103-125.
"Carrés exacts et carrés déductifs." Diagrammes 6 (1981): G1-G17. <http://eudml.org/doc/192983>.
"Qu'est-ce que la logique dans une catégorie ?." Cahiers de Topologie et Géométrie Différentielle Catégoriques 23.2 (1982): 115-148. <http://eudml.org/doc/91293>.

How could a single person, so early in the history of CT (1974!), reach such a profound understanding of 2-dimensional category theory?! I am amazed. I am also amazed by the general tone of his exposition:
image.png
image.png
That point on logic as homological algebra reminds me of Blass' paper on cohomology and the axiom of choice.
Lawvere also has a remark somewhere about logic as homological algebra where multiplication is idempotent

The notion of exact square is also a powerful one. Guitart foresaw the importance of approaching 2-categories from the logical point of view, and apparently also foresaw the notion of 2-topos as a "nice 2-category with a 2-monad playing the role of the powerset construction, i.e. a free cocompletion". The paper on "machines" is a paper on categorical automata theory -sort of.

So, wow.
One has to think back that they were typing all those out on a mechanical typewriter.
That's another source of great awe for me. They had to be careful what they typed.

My father was typing his books on a typewriter like that at the time (but he is prof. of polictical science so very far from technology and maths). It took a huge amount of convincing to get him to move to a computer.
He still types on the computer with two fingers as if it was a mechanical typewriter...
Looking at the first edition of the Revue Diagrammes, I see that they were already talking about Monoidal Categories in 1979...
Yes, "Diagrammes" is another gem.

fosco said:

The notion of exact square is also a powerful one. Guitart foresaw the importance of approaching 2-categories from the logical point of view, and apparently also foresaw the notion of 2-topos as a "nice 2-category with a 2-monad playing the role of the powerset construction, i.e. a free cocompletion". The paper on "machines" is a paper on categorical automata theory -sort of.

What's an exact square? My French is quite rusty

I typed "Deleuze" and "Rene Guitart" into Google and got back this book The French Presemiotic Approach: The Topos of Music III: Gestures. Is that the same Guitart?

One of the abstracts for the articles has:

The French school of diagrammatic philosophers was inspired by Gilles Deleuze’s comments on Bacon [258] and then elaborated upon and deepened by gesture theorists and philosophers, such as Gilles Châtelet [190] and Charles Alunni [24]. This important French approach to gestures reveals a delicate aspect of embodiment in that gestures are conceived as being presemiotic. Gestures—except when ‘tamed’ by social codes—are not signs in a semiotic environment.

The book itself sounds very interesting

This is the third volume of the second edition of the now classic book “The Topos of Music”. The authors present gesture theory, including a gesture philosophy for music, the mathematics of gestures, concept architectures and software for musical gesture theory, the multiverse perspective which reveals the relationship between gesture theory and the string theory in theoretical physics, and applications of gesture theory to a number of musical themes, including counterpoint, modulation theory, free jazz, Hindustani music, and vocal gestures.
He is apparentlly the same Guitart. Amazing.
One of the few philosophers who managed not to ridicule themselves
I find it difficult to tell when someone is a philosopher or a mathematician here. I'd have thought that Rene Guitart is a mathematician. The NLab has a page on him
@Matteo Capucci (he/him) https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/exact+square
ah, I didn't check for a nLab page on exact squares.

by the way, I am in the process of (slowly, lazily) translating a couple of his first papers on exact squares, both as a service to the community, an exercise to revive my French, and a way to study them in depth (following the esoteric tradition of French mathematics, Guitart provides no proof of the theorems).
What I meant is that I'm not just translating them, but also expanding them. I guess the best place to put them is in the "References" section of the nLab page!
Put the translations in the nLab references, too!

Following through that 4 volume tome on the Topos of Music, I found a French Thesis of Philosophy of Category Theory for which Rene Guitart was a reviewer: Diagrammes et Categories. There is a summary in English there.
Seeing the name of Yoneda and Badiou one next to the other sounds like blasphemy
:D I think he is critical of Badiou, who as I understand tries to build all his philosophy on Set theory. I am interested to see how he goes about using Yoneda to do that.

One thing I like to do is watch people talk. Here is Guitart talking at a conference organised by Badiou "Univers algébriques et dualités, pour la dialectique matérialiste de Badiou"
or in English "Algebraic universes and dualities, for the materialist dialectic of Badiou"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ozrJcnnNryk
Badiou tries to build all his philosophy on Set theory, while having poor to absolutely no understanding of the axioms of ZFC; I wouldn't feed his books to pigs.
Guitart is trying to sell him on moving over to the Categories of Categories I think in that talk. (or perhaps he is trying to convince his audience)
I've seen a recent book by Badiou that was all categories and topos theory, so I think he was successful.
I have seen the same book; I had to bleach my soul.
What is the books name?
Well he's going over the theory of sketches to show how one can build quite a lot of mathematics without logic -- sadly I can't clearly see the slides and could not find them online.
It's "Mathematics of the transcendental" in the English translation, published in 2014.
I don't think it's wise to teach a bad philosopher more mathematics; it doesn't make their philosophy any better.
They just get better at impressing and confusing people.

The conference talk I put up above occurred in Prague in 2018, so it happened after that book.
It is good to have people of opposing points of views discuss in a civilised manner though.

Personally I regret that modern mathematics is not a part of “general intellectual discourse” as it seems to have been in the past and I am in favour of any attempt to bring it back there, even if it means that 99% of the non-professional mathematics is bad by professional standards.

It's a bit like Go then: a lot of people play for fun, then there are amateur dan (black belts) and above that a whole level of professional players, and above that the gods. Because of the flexible handicap system each person can play nine stones down and nine stones up on that hierarchy. (I play on a 9x9 board with my four year olds, and they can beat me 50% of the time)
In mathematics and most human situations things are much more complex, because there is not just one game, but many different games people are playing within different (academic or other) disciplines.

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

It's "Mathematics of the transcendental" in the English translation, published in 2014.

I read that in a reading group during my masters a few years back. It was fine, in the sense that the topos theory was formally correct. Not sure he managed to fit anything original into the package, though.
That’s the impression I got. Most of the mathematics itself is correct, it’s just that he derives possibly unjustified philosophical consequences
Which are perhaps too couched in the language of the academy to discern for interest.
There certainly are interesting philosophical insights to be gleaned from CT. Just look at the papers on structuralism by Awodey.
Or some of the papers in the book ‘Categories for the working philosopher’
I feel that Badiou is a negative / revisionist influence in dialectical materialism, and that he also doesn't understand any of the set theory or topos theory that he "uses". He is an obscurantist!

And yeah, it is hard to find good philosophical uses of category theory... Philosophers love to attach undue significance to various things and just miss every possible point. But I thought Steve's papers were really nice.

In my experience, philosphers tend to make almost uniformly poor "interventions" into mathematics, because the mathematics involves a lot of subtleties and motivations that are hard to understand without a common frame of reference. Mathematicians rarely intervene in philosophy, but I think there is sometimes a good result.

Mathematicians do philsophy constantly "by accident", in the sense that new (and fruitful) philosophical ideas stem from hygienic mathematical practice. I still have to see a philosopher proving a theorem "by accident", and this fact alone marks their inferiority in the scale of disciplines.
Anyway, let's keep this thread about Guitart('s mathematics) if possible.
Fosco: Jean -Marc Cordier and I used exact squares in our book on Shape Theory. It is a very pretty idea.
Yes! I agree. Guitart mentions applications to shape theory (in a recent paper about absolute and contractible squares).
As I said in reply to Fosco, there is a section on Exact squares in my book with Jean-Marc Cordier (and it is in English!).
Can you briefly sketch how the notion turns out to be useful in shape theory (or give a pointer in the book)?
Do exact squares satisfy a pasting law similar to pullbacks? I guess yes (the closure under composition is mentioned)
What is a clever way to prove that you can cancel an exact square on the right of an exact pasting, to obtain exactness of the left square?

The book is: Shape Theory: Categorical Methods of Approximation, Mathematics and its Applications, Ellis Horwood Ltd., March 1989, 207 pages; Dover Edition, 2008. (I include both references as someone may find the first addition in their library. The two editions do not differ at all,... except for the publisher.)
The context is the categorical theory of shape. I think that that is not that well known so it is difficult to summarise enough to give a sketch here.
PS I do not get any royalties from the Dover edition and the other is way out of print.

fosco said:

by the way, I am in the process of (slowly, lazily) translating a couple of his first papers on exact squares, both as a service to the community, an exercise to revive my French, and a way to study them in depth (following the esoteric tradition of French mathematics, Guitart provides no proof of the theorems).

Hi, you could just write to Rene' Guitart, who's very approachable, uses his computer quite a lot and will probably be flattered by your "crush"! let me know if you need the email address.
@Valeria de Paiva yes, please, send me a PM :heart:

Now that there is a separate discussion for Guitart in philosophy, I'd like to use this thread for a mathematical question. Are exact squares where one corner is the terminal object interesting for something?

I can do the math and find what is a condition for a 2-cell to fill an exact square where the upper left, or lower right corner is terminal; the other two are (0,1)-dual to each other and behave similarly.
There is at least the example of final functors on the nlab page (with two occurrences of the terminal category).
Yes, in that case _both_ lower objects are terminal; I am interested in something more general here :smile:

Anyway, @Valeria de Paiva unfortunately Guitart is not responding to my message

Perhaps my bad French offended him :-( j'espère que non...
perhaps he's on holidays. It's a big thing in France :-)
@Henry Story Outch... :sweat_smile: But René Guitart is retired, isn't he?

yes, there are a lot of possibly stories that are coherent with the very very little information we have. Epistemically we are it seems, on this topic (and most others for that matter), smeared across a huge set of possible worlds, not knowing which one we are actually inhabiting.

So, reading the paper

"Carrés exacts et carrés déductifs." Diagrammes 6 (1981): G1-G17. <http://eudml.org/doc/192983>

I encountered a notion I can't really make sense of. Let me translate in a more modern language the situation Guitart works in.

Definition. An extensor (extenseur) or an extension structure on a category C\mathcal CC is a function E:Span(X,Y)→C(X,Y)E : \textsf{Span}(X,Y) \to \mathcal C(X,Y)E:Span(X,Y)→C(X,Y) sending a span (X←pA,A→fY)(X \xleftarrow{p} A, A \xrightarrow{f} Y)(Xp​A,Af​Y) to an arrow Ep(f):X→YE_p(f) : X \to YEp​(f):X→Y,

The correspondence EEE subject to the following axioms:

  1. For every pair of composable arrows p,qp,qp,q we have Eq∘p(f)=Eq(Ep(f))E_{q\circ p}(f)=E_q(E_p(f))Eq∘p​(f)=Eq​(Ep​(f))
  2. Given a pullback square A→p′Bh′↓↓hC→pD\begin{array}{ccc}A &\overset{p'}\to& B \\_{h'}\downarrow && \downarrow_h\\C &\underset{p}\to& D \end{array}Ah′​↓C​→p′p→​​B↓h​D​ then Ep(f)∘h=Ep′(f∘h′)E_p(f)\circ h = E_{p'}(f\circ h')Ep​(f)∘h=Ep′​(f∘h′)
  3. If we have a diagram ←p⇆h′h→q\xleftarrow{p} \underset{h}{\overset{h'}\leftrightarrows} \xrightarrow{q}p​h⇆h′​​q​ such that ph′h=pph'h=pph′h=p and qhh′=qqhh'=qqhh′=q, then Eq(fph′)=Eq(Eh(fp))E_q(fph')=E_q(E_h(fp))Eq​(fph′)=Eq​(Eh​(fp)).

Obscure as these properties may seem, they serve to abstract the properties enjoyed by the left or right extension bifunctor in a 2-category that admits enough structure.

Now, in his "Carrés exacts et carrés déductifs." Guitart claims that whenever P\boldsymbol PP is a KZ-monad on a 2-category K\mathcal KK, then for every span f:I→E,h:I→Jf : I \to E, h : I \to Jf:I→E,h:I→J, and every P\boldsymbol PP-algebra EEE, the arrow

Exh(f):=J→PJ→h∗PI→f∗PE→E\text{Ex}_h(f) := J \to \boldsymbol P J \xrightarrow{h^*} \boldsymbol P I \xrightarrow{f_*} \boldsymbol P E \to EExh​(f):=J→PJh∗​PIf∗​​PE→E

defines an extension structure (page 7 of the paper), and this sets up a deduction structure (previous page).

I haven't the faintest idea how this can be, for two reasons:

  • First, the definition in the paper lacks some information (I have adapted the definition that Guitart gives, without further mention, using -probably?- the correspondent of hhh in the Kleisli category of P\boldsymbol PP) that I'm not sure I filled up properly.
  • Second, and more important, the definition of a deductive structure is given as follows: it is a relation ⊢\vdash⊢ from the set of finite subsets of a set EEE to EEE itself, in such a way that if we denote it as an infix operator Γ⊢x\Gamma \vdash xΓ⊢x, whe Γ\GammaΓ is a finite subset {a1,…,an}\{a_1,\dots, a_n\}{a1​,…,an​} of EEE and x∈Ex\in Ex∈E, a bunch of axioms are satisfied (to the effect that ⊢\vdash⊢ behaves like the entailment relation for a set of formulas).

Now, however, the deductive structure induced by an extension structure is defined as follows:

image.png

Not only I don't have the faintest idea about how to extend this definition to make sense for a tuple of morphisms to the left of the entailment relation, but I also haven't got any idea of how to prove that {f}⊢Exf\{f\}\vdash_{\text{Ex}} f{f}⊢Ex​f and that if {f}⊢Exg\{f\}\vdash_{\text{Ex}} g{f}⊢Ex​g and {g}⊢Exf\{g\}\vdash_{\text{Ex}} f{g}⊢Ex​f, then f=gf=gf=g. For the first, does it follows that Ex1f=f\text{Ex}_1 f=fEx1​f=f? And for the second... I'm even more clueless.

Any help?
Let me clarify: does it follow from the axioms of an extenseur that E1(f)=fE_1(f)=fE1​(f)=f? The only thing I'm able to prove at first sight is that E1=E1∘E1E_1 = E_1\circ E_1E1​=E1​∘E1​.
This topic was moved by Matteo Capucci (he/him) to #theory: category theory > questions about "Carrés exacts et carrés déductifs"
